page.title: 18Dry-Stone Walls.
page.content: Dry-stone walls using the abundant local stone, are a feature of many fields in North Northumberland. They are called 'dykes'locally. A shallow trench is dug where the wall is to be built. The builder starts with his stones in two courses-side by side, with the smoother faces outwards and sloping slightly inwards for stability. The vertical joints are staggered and all gaps filled with chosen fragments, the builder maintaining his level throughout using a string line. The wall tapers from the base upwards and is topped with large stones set vertically. No cement or mortar is used and the only tools are a hammer and a string line.
